description: From Latin aberrāns, present active participle of aberrō (“go astray; err”), from ab (“from”) + errō (“to wander”). See aberr.

adjectives.description: aberrant (comparative more aberrant, superlative most aberrant)

entries.meaning: Differing from the norm. [First attested sometime between the mid 16th century and the early 17th century.]
examples: Synonyms: abnormal, exceptional, unusual; see also Thesaurus:strange
Antonyms: normal, regular, true; see also Thesaurus:normal

entries.meaning: (sometimes figuratively) Straying from the right way; deviating from morality or truth. [First attested in the mid 18th century.]
examples: Synonyms: devious, errant, immoral; see also Thesaurus:immoral
Antonyms: correct, right, straight; see also Thesaurus:virtuous

entries.meaning: (botany, zoology) Deviating from the ordinary or natural type; exceptional; abnormal. [First attested in the mid 19th century.]
A person or object that deviates from the rest of a group.
(biology) A group, individual, or structure that deviates from the usual or natural type, especially with an atypical chromosome number.
